pageData.text: In this investigation, students will extract pigments from spinach, then perform to identify the pigments using two solvent solutions and the Rf value of the pigment.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes
Activity 1: TLC Using Solvent 1 – 45 minutes
Activity 2: TLC Using Solvent 2 – 45 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Thin-Layer Chromatography of Spinach Extract

text: Perform a separation of plant pigments using <button class=glossary-text>thin-layer chromatography</button>.
Determine the relative polarity of plant pigments based on the Rf value of the TLC plate.
Calculate Rf values of plant pigments.

pageData.text: HPTLC refers to High Performance <button class=glossary-text>Thin-Layer Chromatography</button>. It is like traditional thin-layer chromatography (TLC) but has significantly shorter developing times, uses less solvent, and produces results with improved resolution. The test is also highly reproducible, which is important for confirming results. Because of these characteristics, the high performance version of TLC has found a home in forensic toxicology, among other disciplines. Forensic toxicologists are often called upon to identify unknown poisonous substances in cases that involve lethal intoxication.

For example, a surprising number of cases involving sedative and hypnotic drugs used as doping agents occur during travel. The motive is to steal the traveler’s cash and other valuables while they are drugged. In one case, four victims were traveling on an express train where they were each offered a cup of tea by a fellow passenger. After consuming the tea, the victims fell unconscious. Upon waking up, they found their belongings were missing, which led them to file a report with the local police. The toxicology tests performed on the victims’ blood, using HPTLC technology, showed positive results for oxazepam, a prescription sedative. Police eventually tracked down and apprehended a suspect, who had oxazepam pills on their person.

pageData.desc: A train at a train station.
pageData.altText: A train at a train station.

pageData.text: The analysis of many compounds requires that the components be separated and studied individually. One of the most powerful techniques used to separate substances is chromatography, which involves partitioning substances between mobile and <button class=glossary-text>stationary phases</button>. Different types of chromatography have different scientific applications.

is one type of chromatography, in which a thin layer of adsorbent particles (silica gel) is attached to a solid plate to form the stationary phase. The stationary phase is the solid or liquid phase of a chromatography system on which the materials to be separated are selectively adsorbed. A small amount of sample is applied (spotted) near the bottom of the plate, and the plate is placed in the . The mobile phase is the liquid or gas that flows through a chromatography system, moving the materials to be separated at different rates over the stationary phase. The solvent is drawn up by capillary action, and dissolves the components of the sample, which then migrate upward along the plate to varying distances depending on their ability to interact with the stationary and mobile phases.

TLC can be used to separate pigments. Both chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b readily form hydrogen bonds with silica gel. Pheophytin a and b are slightly less polar. Carotenoids are divided into two main classes: carotenes and xanthophylls. Xanthophylls contain oxygen; carotenes are pure hydrocarbons. Carotenes do not form hydrogen bonds with the silica gel. They produce a faint yellow band toward the top of the developed TLC plate. Xanthophylls are oxygen containing derivatives of carotenoids.

pageData.question: What can thin-layer chromatography be used for?

options.text: to separate pigments
to separate hydroxyl groups
to separate mixtures of silica gel
to create stationary phases
to create mobile phases

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Thin-layer chromatography can be used to separate pigments.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes thin-layer chromatography?

options.text: Compounds applied to a stationary phase separate out as a mobile phase flows through the system.
Compounds dissolved in a mobile phase separate out by density over time.
Compounds are synthesized on a stationary phase and cleaned with a mobile phase rinse.
Compounds dissolved in a stationary phase separate out by pH over time.
Compounds applied to a stationary phase separate out as electricity flows through the system.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A small amount of sample is applied near the bottom of the plate (stationary phase), and the plate is placed in a liquid or gas (mobile phase) that flows through the chromatography system, moving the materials to be separated at different rates over the stationary phase.

hintData.body: Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) is one type of chromatography, in which a thin layer of adsorbent particles (silica gel) is attached to a solid plate to form the stationary phase. The stationary phase is the solid or liquid phase of a chromatography system on which the materials to be separated are selectively adsorbed. A small amount of sample is applied (spotted) near the bottom of the plate, and the plate is placed in the mobile phase. The mobile phase is the liquid or gas that flows through a chromatography system, moving the materials to be separated at different rates over the stationary phase. Both chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b readily form hydrogen bonds with silica gel. Pheophytin a and b are slightly less polar. Carotenoids are divided into two main classes: carotenes and xanthophylls. Xanthophylls contain oxygen; carotenes are pure hydrocarbons. Carotenes do not form hydrogen bonds with the silica gel. They produce a faint yellow band toward the top of the developed TLC plate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) is one type of chromatography, in which a thin layer of adsorbent particles (silica gel) is attached to a solid plate to form the stationary phase. The stationary phase is the solid or liquid phase of a chromatography system on which the materials to be separated are selectively adsorbed. A small amount of sample is applied (spotted) near the bottom of the plate, and the plate is placed in the mobile phase. The mobile phase is the liquid or gas that flows through a chromatography system, moving the materials to be separated at different rates over the stationary phase. Both chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b readily form hydrogen bonds with silica gel. Pheophytin a and b are slightly less polar. Carotenoids are divided into two main classes: carotenes and xanthophylls. Xanthophylls contain oxygen; carotenes are pure hydrocarbons. Carotenes do not form hydrogen bonds with the silica gel. They produce a faint yellow band toward the top of the developed TLC plate.

pageData.text: They produce yellow to orange bands and are generally less polar than chlorophyll a and b.

Both trials in this experiment use the same (silica gel). Pigments that are attracted to the silica gel will not travel as far up the TLC plate as pigments that are not as strongly attracted to it. Solvent 1 contains acetone, which is less polar than the silica gel but much more polar than the hexane in Solvent 2. Solvent 1 will produce three bands: chlorophylls, xanthophylls, and carotenes. Separation between the different types of chlorophylls, xanthophylls, and carotenes will not be visible. Due to the larger difference in polarity between hexane and the silica gel, Solvent 2 should produce more pigment bands with better separation. Chlorophyll a and b will separate, and there is the possibility of students seeing faint chlorophyll bands that are likely isomers of chlorophyll a and b. A number of different xanthophylls might also separate.

Separation occurs as each component, being different in chemical and physical composition, interacts with the stationary and to a different degree, creating individual bands on the plate. The retardation factor, or the Rf value, is used to characterize and compare components of various samples.
<button class=resource-text>Equation 1</button>.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Rf value = distance from origin to component spot over distance from origin to solvent front
pageData.desc: Equation 1: Rf value = distance from origin to component spot over distance from origin to solvent front

pageData.text: The pigments in vegetables, flowers, and leaves can be separated and identified by using . Green pigments, known as chlorophylls, serve as the main photoreceptor molecules of plants. Yellow pigments, called carotenoids aid the plant in the photosynthesis process. In addition, xanthophylls, which are contained in chloroplasts, can also be isolated and identified using chromatographic techniques. Chlorophylls and carotenoids are primarily composed of long hydrocarbon chains that are nonpolar and insoluble in water. In general, chlorophylls and carotenoids are very soluble in alkanes and ketones, and slightly less soluble in alcohols. Alkanes are pure hydrocarbons and are nonpolar molecules. Ketones and alcohols are hydrocarbons that contain oxygen atoms attached to the carbon chains. The areas around the oxygen atoms are polar. In this activity, you will use one solvent that is composed of a ketone (Solvent 1) and a different solvent composed of an alcohol and a ketone (Solvent 2). Possible pigments found in spinach are in Table 1.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes why using hexane as the TLC solvent will yield more pigments with better separation than acetone?

options.text: The polarity difference between hexane and the TLC plate is larger than the difference between acetone and the plate.
The polarity difference between hexane and the TLC plate is smaller than the difference between acetone and the plate.
The pigments to be separated do not dissolve as well in hexane as they do acetone.
The pigments to be separated become sensitive to light when dissolved in hexane.
Hexane is not as volatile as acetone and will remain on the plate longer.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Due to the larger difference in polarity between hexane and the silica gel, hexane solvent should produce more pigment bands with better separation than acetone solvent.

pageData.question: There are five pigments in a plant sample being separated by thin-layer chromatography. Of these pigments, Pigment 1 is the most polar. Which of the following best describes the relative movement of Pigment 1 along the stationary phase?

options.text: It will travel the farthest distance along the stationary phase.
It will travel the shortest distance along the stationary phase.
It will travel half the distance the solvent travels through the stationary phase.
The relative movement of Pigment 1 depends on the Rf value of the solvent.
The relative movement of Pigment 1 depends on the amount of solvent used.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pigment 1 will travel the farthest distance along the stationary phase. Pigments that are less polar are more attracted to the silica gel than the solvent and will not travel as far up the TLC plate as pigments that are more polar, which are more attracted to the solvent than the silica gel.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Both trials in this experiment use the same stationary phase (silica gel). Pigments that are attracted to the silica gel will not travel as far up the TLC plate as pigments that are not as strongly attracted to it. Solvent 1 contains acetone, which is less polar than silica gel but much more polar than the hexane in Solvent 2. Due to the larger difference in polarity between hexane and silica gel, Solvent 2 should produce more pigment bands with better separation. Separation occurs as each component, being different in chemical and physical composition, interacts with the stationary and mobile phases to a different degree, creating individual bands on the plate. The retardation factor, or the Rf value, is used to characterize and compare components of various samples.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. To prepare, extract the spinach leaf pigments with acetone. Begin Activity 1 by creating a development chamber using acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 1 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. To prepare, extract the spinach leaf pigments with acetone. Begin Activity 1 by creating a development chamber using acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 1 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band.

pageData.desc: Finally, save the acetone solvent for Activity 2. Begin Activity 2 by creating a development chamber using hexane and acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 2 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band. Finally, compare the pigment bands between TLC plates 1 and 2. .
pageData.altText: Finally, save the acetone solvent for Activity 2. Begin Activity 2 by creating a development chamber using hexane and acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 2 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band. Finally, compare the pigment bands between TLC plates 1 and 2.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the investigation. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Acetone and hexane are flammable. Keep chemicals away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Acetone and hexane cause skin irritation, eye irritation, and respiratory irritation. Use caution and wear all personal protective equipment while handling chemicals. The chemicals in this investigation should be used in a well ventilated room with some active ventilation. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan.

assestmentData.question: If the substance of a mixture separated by thin-layer chromatography travels 42 mm while the solvent front travels 60 mm, what is the Rf value of the substance?

Pigment A forms hydrogen bonds with silica gel more readily than does Pigment B. Which of the following best describes the relative movements of each band during thin-layer chromatography as the pigments move along a silica gel plate?

options.text: Pigment A will not travel as far as Pigment B.
Pigment A will travel farther than Pigment B.
Pigment A will travel as far as Pigment B.
Pigment A will travel faster than Pigment B.
Pigment A will not travel along the plate at all.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following solvents will be used to perform thin-layer chromatography in this investigation?

options.text: acetone and hexane
ethanol and methanol
acetone, hexane and methanol
octane and hexane
water, acetone and ethanol

assestmentData.question: Which of the following solvents would provide superior pigment separation during thin-layer chromatography?

options.text: A solvent that is more polar than the stationary phase.
A solvent that has a higher pH than the stationary phase.
A solvent that has a higher temperature than the stationary phase.
A solvent that is more radioactive than the stationary phase.
A solvent that is denser than the stationary phase.

options.text: They are environmental toxins.
They are flammable.
They are eye irritants.

They are skin irritants.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Remove the stems from the spinach leaves, and then mass approximately 5 grams of leaves.
Use scissors to cut the spinach leaves into small pieces, and then place the pieces in a glass test tube.

Add 5 mL of 100% acetone to the test tube. Carefully mash the mixture with the thermometer. Let the mixture stand in the test tube stand for 15 minutes to allow the pigments to be extracted by the acetone.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will perform <button class=glossary-text>thin-layer chromatography</button> on the spinach extract using Solvent 1. You will then calculate the R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> value of each pigment on the chromatogram.
Using a graduated cylinder, add 20 mL of acetone to the 250-mL beaker, which is the developing chamber.
Handle the TLC plates by their edges using forceps. Set the plates on a paper towel with the plastic side down.

Use a pencil to lightly draw a horizontal line exactly 1.5 cm from the bottom edge of each TLC plate, as shown in Figure 1. This is the “origin line,” where you will spot the plate with the spinach extract.
Use a pencil to label the top of one TLC plate “S1” for Solvent 1. Label the top of the second TLC plate “S2” for Solvent 2. The “S2” plate will be used during Activity 2.
Important: (a) Do not press your pencil down too hard, because doing so will remove the silica gel (the adsorbent substrate) from the TLC plate. (b) Do not use a pen to mark the TLC plate.

Refer to Figure 2. Use a capillary tube to place two small drops of spinach extract sample on the origin line of the “S1” TLC plate. The two spots should be placed approximately one-third in from the edge of the plate, and one-third the width of the plate from each other, as shown. Allow the spots to dry.
In order to control the size of the drop of extract, keep your finger on the open end of the capillary tube.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram showing where origin line should be drawn on TLC plate
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing where origin line should be drawn on TLC plate

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram showing where samples should be spotted on origin line on TLC plate
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing where samples should be spotted on origin line on TLC plate

pageData.text: Repeat the spotting procedure four additional times at the same two places on the “S1” TLC plate. Let the spots dry between each additional application of the sample. Allow the plate to air dry completely before proceeding, which should take 3 to 4 minutes.

After the plate is completely dry, pick the plate up by its edges using forceps. Carry it to the developing chamber. Avoid touching the surface of the TLC plate; this is likely to invalidate your results.
Carefully place the TLC plate in the chamber with the spotted end toward the solvent. Cover the beaker with a sheet of paper.

Allow the solvent front to move up the TLC plate for 45 minutes or until it reaches 1 cm from the top edge, whichever comes first. Check on the progress every 1–2 minutes. Do not allow the solvent front to reach the top of the plate.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Use forceps to remove the TLC strip from the chamber. Place the strip on a paper towel to dry.
Immediately mark the location of the solvent front with a pencil before it evaporates, as seen in .
Allow the TLC plate to dry in a well-ventilated area. Set aside the developing chamber with the acetone still inside for Activity 2.
Use a pencil to mark the center of each pigment band. Number the bands on the plate, with Band 1 being the one nearest the sample origin line. Record the band colors in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Be prepared to act quickly once the plate has dried. As soon as the TLC plate is exposed to air, some bands will start to change color.
Beginning at the origin line, measure the distance traveled by the solvent front and each of the numbered pigment bands. Record the results in Data Table 1.
Remember, Band 1 is the pigment band nearest the origin line at the bottom of the plate.
Calculate the Rf value for each observed band using . Record the values in Data Table 1.
Use the graduated cylinder to measure out 3 mL of the acetone remaining in the development chamber. You will use this in Activity 2.

Dispose of the remaining acetone solvent in the developing chamber by pouring it down the drain with water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solution. Dry the beaker thoroughly with a paper towel.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram showing how the distance traveled by a substance and the distance traveled by the solvent front should be measured on a TLC plate
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing how the distance traveled by a substance and the distance traveled by the solvent front should be measured on a TLC plate

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will perform on the spinach extract using Solvent 2. You will then calculate the Rf value of each pigment on the chromatogram.
Repeat the procedure, adding 7 mL of hexane and 3 mL of acetone in the developing chamber as the solvent, and the TLC plate labeled “S2.” Remove the plate when the front is 1 cm from the top.
Number and measure the bands as you did for Solvent 1. Record your findings in Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Calculate the Rf value for each observed band using . Record the values in Data Table 2.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
TLC plates and used spinach can be disposed of in the trash.

pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. To prepare, extract the spinach leaf pigments with acetone. Begin Activity 1 by creating a development chamber using acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 1 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band.

Finally, save the acetone solvent for Activity 2. Begin Activity 2 by creating a development chamber using hexane and acetone. Next, spot TLC plate 2 with spinach extract and allow the plate to air dry. Then, place the plate in the development chamber. Allow the solvent to move toward the top edge of the plate until it is 1 centimeter from the edge. Once solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top edge, remove the plate from the development chamber and immediately mark the location of the solvent front on the plate. Then, allow the plate to air dry. Once the plate is completely dry, mark the location of each pigment band on the plate. Next, measure the distances traveled by the solvent front and pigment bands. Then, calculate the Rf values of each pigment band. Finally, compare the pigment bands between TLC plates 1 and 2.

data.title: Mobile phase
data.content: Is the liquid or gas that flows through a chromatography system, moving the materials to be separated at different rates over the stationary phase

data.title: Stationary phase
data.content: Is the solid or liquid phase of a chromatography system on which the materials to be separated are selectively adsorbed

data.title: Thin-layer chromatography (TLC)
data.content: One type of chromatography in which a thin layer of adsorbent particles is attached to a solid plate (stationary phase). The plate is placed in a solvent (mobile phase), which is drawn up by capillary action and dissolves the adsorbent particles, which then migrate upward along the plate to varying distances depending on their ability to interact with the stationary and mobile phases.
